title: Confirming your participation
body: Please complete this product in sequence because the topics are structured to build on one another. Some quizzes and scenarios are included to encourage you to think critically about, and put into practice, the content presented. Your answers to the quizzes will not be stored or logged anywhere. They are for your use only.

title: Conclusion
body:
You have been introduced to:

  • the three official documents that guide your ethical conduct and form a part of your terms and conditions of employment.

We will learn more about the CBSA Code of Conduct throughout this course.

title: Objectives
body:
The objective of this module is to provide you with an orientation to the official guiding documents related to values and ethics.

In this module you will be introduced to:

  • the three guiding documents that relate to ethical conduct, and how they form a part of your terms and conditions of employment.

title: Terms and Conditions of Employment
body:
The Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector and the Policy on Conflict of Interest and Post-Employment (TBS) are the umbrella guidance documents on ethical behaviour for all public servants.  They are a part of your terms and conditions of employment because you are a public servant.

The CBSA Code of Conduct has been revised and customized to address our organizational mandate and culture, and it takes into consideration our ethical risks.

This Code is a part of your terms and conditions of employment because you are a CBSA employee.

We will now take a closer look at each of these documents.

title: How to use this course
instruction: Select each tab for more information about the use of the course.

_items.title: Glossary of Acronyms
_items.body: In the Learning Resources toolbar above, you will find a Glossary of the acronyms that are used throughout this course. You can refer to this as needed.

_items.title: Icons
_items.body:
Key Points

As you go through this course, you will come across slides that display the key image in the bottom left corner of the slide. The key signals that you can reveal a key point on the topic about which you are learning.

Dig Deeper

As you go through this course, you will also come across slides that display the bulb image in the bottom left corner of the slide. The bulb signals that you can reveal additional information related to this topic. If you want to dig deeper, click on the bulb to go to this information.

Manager Icon

As you go through this course, you will also come across slides that display the magnifying glass in the bottom left corner of the slide. The magnifying glass signals that you can reveal additional information important to managers.

Reference

Whenever you see this icon use it to refer to the Code of Conduct.

title: Terms and Conditions of Employment
instruction:
Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector
Policy on Conflict of Interest and Post-Employment (TBS)
CBSA Code of Conduct

title: Official documents
body:
The Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector (VECPS), the Policy on Conflict of Interest and Post-Employment (TBS), and the CBSA’s Code of Conduct  (CBSA Code) are terms and conditions of employment.

The CBSA Code states: “We understand that an action or inaction on our part that is not in keeping with these laws, rules and regulations, Codes and the Policy is considered misconduct and will entail CBSA disciplinary measures up to and including termination of employment.” 

  • (Chapter 1, B. Accountability and Professional Conduct.)

These include, but are not limited to, the Customs Act, the Criminal Code of Canada, the Financial Administration Act, the Canada Evidence Act, the Access to Information Act, the Privacy Act, the Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act, the Policy on Government Security, various collective agreements, etc.
instruction: Select each of the tabs to the left to find out more about each of the official guiding documents related to ethical conduct at CBSA.

_items.title: VECPS
_items.body:
The objectives of the Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector are:

  • To articulate the values and expected behaviours that guide public servants in all activities related to their professional duties;
  • To contribute to public confidence in the integrity of all public institutions; and
  • To strengthen the ethical culture of the public sector.

The Treasury Board Secretariat’s Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector came into effect on April 15, 2012 and replaced the previous TBS Code: The Values and Ethics Code for the Public Service.  The new code uses the term “sector”, whereas the previous code used the term “service”.

_items.title: Policy on Conflict of Interest and Post-Employment (TBS)
_items.body:
This policy elaborates on the Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector, and is aligned with its content. It provides direction and measures to assist organizations and public servants in effectively dealing with real, potential and apparent conflict of interest situations which may arise during and after employment in the public service. Preventing, managing or resolving conflict of interest situations is one of the principal means of maintaining public trust and confidence in the impartiality and integrity of the public service.

This policy is to be read in conjunction with the Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector.

Issues related to conflict of interest will be addressed in module 6 of this training.

_items.title: CBSA Code of Conduct
_items.body:
It is well recognized that each organization within the federal public sector has its own culture and operational requirements. As such, the Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDPA) requires that each federal organization develop and implement its own organizational code, and that it be consistent with the overarching VECPS and the new Policy. CBSA took this as an opportunity to update its Code of Conduct and conducted extensive consultations at HQ and in the regions with employees, managers, senior management, and stakeholders. The revised CBSA Code of Conduct came into force in September 2012.

The CBSA Code of Conduct will be described in more detail further in this training.

title: Quick Quiz
body: Before we look at the CBSA Code of Conduct, take the time now to test your knowledge of what official documents guide your ethical conduct and as employees form a part of our terms and conditions of employment.

title: Introduction
body:
The role of the Office of Values and Ethics at CBSA

This learning product was developed by the Office of Values and Ethics (OVE) in the National Integrity Centre of Expertise, Labour Relations Branch.

The Office provides advice, recommendations and guidance to all employees on the CBSA Code of Conduct, policies and other key documents that guide ethical behaviour.

The Office is separate from the Security and Professional Standards Division.  As such, the OVE is not involved with administrative investigations.

title: Course Objectives
body:
In developing this course, the Office of Values and Ethics had five specific objectives in mind:

  • To increase employee knowledge of the official values and ethics documents that form a part of their terms and conditions of employment;
  • To raise values and ethics awareness in the workplace and off-duty, and recognize issues related to values and ethics;
  • To develop ethical leadership competencies;
  • To develop employees’ capacity to recognize impediments to ethical decision-making; and to know when to seek assistance; and
  • To provide tools and resources to help employees meet their obligations and responsibilities related to values and ethics.

title: Objectives
body:
The objective of this module is to orient you to obstacles or challenges you might face in demonstrating your ethical competency.

In this module you will be introduced to:

  • the possible challenges to ethical conduct in the workplace.

title: Conclusion
body:
• You should now have a greater understanding of how values and ethics influence your on- and off-duty life, and where to go if you are ever in doubt about what is expected of you.
  • You can build your ethical decision-making skills and demonstrate values-based leadership by talking about values and ethics in your workplace using the ethical dialogue model. For more resources, visit the Values and Ethics page on Atlas.
  • We all have a responsibility to live the values of Respect, Integrity and Professionalism in our workplace day-to-day…in doing so, we act as ethical leaders.

title: Objectives
body:
The objective of this module is to help you develop ethical leadership competencies and recognize obstacles to ethical decision-making.

In this module you will be introduced to:

  • the Insight Method to ethical decision-making; and
  • ethical dialogue.

title: Objectives
body:
The objective of this module is to provide you with an awareness of the Internal Disclosure of Wrongdoing process.

In this module you will:

  • be introduced to the Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDPA) or the Act;
  • learn how to disclose wrongdoing; and
  • apply ethics as “a way of life” by delving into a scenario.

title: Objectives
body:
The objective of this module is to provide an orientation to Chapter 2, Conflict of Interest and Post-Employment.

In this module you will:

  • Explore the three types of conflict of interest  and conflict of duties by reflecting on scenarios.
  • Apply ethics as a "way of life”.

title: Objectives
body:
The objective of this module is to introduce you to Chapter 1, Sections 3, 4, 9, and 15 of the CBSA Code of Conduct.

In this module you will:

  • learn how your off-duty and on-duty lives may intersect when ethics is viewed as a “way of life”

title: Objectives
body:
The objective of this module is to provide you with a deeper understanding of the concepts of “values” and “ethics” and to help you facilitate discussions related to these concepts.

In this module you will:

  • reflect on your values and compare them to the VECPS and the CBSA Code values;
  • better understand how ethics informs your conduct; and
  • discover the three levels of integrity.

title: Case Study

title: Introduction
body: What comes to mind when you hear the word... values?

title: Values
instruction: Select each tab to learn more information.

_items.title: What are values?
_items.body:
Values are enduring fundamental beliefs that influence our attitudes, decisions, choices, actions and behaviours.

Often when we are angry it is because one or more of our values have been breached.Values are about what is important to use and what we care about.

_items.title: Where do values come from?
_items.body:
Values come from many places:

  • Family and upbringing
  • Religion
  • School and academia
  • Culture and subculture
  • Society and socialization
  • Friends and peer groups
  • Experiences
  • Workplace
  • Institutions
  • History

We tend to adopt the values we have grown up with and believe that they are the right ones.

_items.title: Do values change over time?
_items.body: Although the name of the value may remain the same, how we enact the value can change over time.

title: Your Values
instruction: What are your values?

_items.placeholder: Type them in this box and submit by clicking the button.

_feedback.correct: Now pick your top three values and think about why you picked these in particular.

_incorrect.final: Now pick your top three values and think about why you picked these in particular.

title: Your values
body:
These top values are what we call the “line in the sand” values. We would almost never choose to go against our most important values.

  • Refer to Chapter 1, A. Our Values and read the definitions for each of the public sector and CBSA values.

Compare these to your top three picks. Are there any conflicts?

title: Values Compatibility
body:
Our personal values affect the decisions we make, and cannot be separated from our work life. By identifying our personal values we are better equipped to live out these values at work. There may be differences between our values and the public sector or the CBSA values. It is important to recognize when these differences result in some type of conflict.

Some values are commonly shared but not all and not all the time. Also, some people prioritize their values differently from you. We see differences between populations, generations and cultures, between families and groups, between professions and workplaces, and between family members.

The diversity of people in our organization is important, and with this diversity comes different values. Diversity, as a Canadian value, implies that we respect our mutual differences and strive to work together with the belief that our differences make us better.

It is important to understand that, as public servants, our duty is always to ensure that our private interests do not conflict with the public interest.

If you are finding it difficult to negotiate these values conflicts, you can seek help from your manager or from an advisor in the Office of Values and Ethics, an Informal Conflict Mediator or an Employee Assistance Program Practitioner. They can help you discover options.

_items.title: Values Compatibility Tip
_items.body: If you are finding it difficult to negotiate these values conflicts, you can seek help from your manager or from an advisor in the Office of Values and Ethics, an Informal Conflict Mediator or an Employee Assistance Program Practitioner. They can help you discover options.

title: Values (cont'd)
body:
• Your personal values influence the decisions you make, and cannot be separated from your work life.
  • Other people will prioritize their values differently from you, or subject them to various limitations.
  • You don’t have to eliminate these differences, but you do need to recognize that they exist so you can mediate the conflicts between personal and work-related values when they arise.

Ethics goes hand in hand with values.

title: Ethics
body: Do these images represent your understanding of ethics?
instruction:
Select on each image below and think about the questions.
Select the summary button after you have reflected on this.

_items.title: The Rules
_items.body: Is ethics about stopping people from breaking the rules?

_items.title: Exclamation mark
_items.body: Is ethics about imperatives, or statements to the effect that you must do this or that?

_items.title: Handcuffs
_items.body: Is ethics mostly concerned about catching the bad guys and gals? With punishing criminals?

_items.title: Good/Evil
_items.body: Is ethics about good vs. evil?

_items.title: Wrong/Right
_items.body: Is ethics is about wrong vs. right?

title: Ethics
body:
We have been conditioned to think that ethics is about catching the bad guys/gals; that it is mostly concerned with punishing criminals, and stopping people from breaking the rules, or that it is about good versus evil or right versus wrong, or imperatives such as “you shall not.” Blockbuster movies and our media reinforce this understanding of ethics.

Notice how this understanding is focused on others (bad guys/gals, criminals, rule-breakers, evil-doers or wrong-doers),  and not on ourselves. It is common for people to think that they have the right viewpoint. Why? Because we understand ourselves as ethical people and we would be right to think so.  But, if we consider how we came to be ethical persons, we would discover that we learned how to think and act this way.  The opportunity to continue to learn never stops as we encounter new, different and often difficult situations that test our ethics-related skills.

title: What is Ethics?
instruction: Select each tab to learn more information.

_items.title: Etymology
_items.body: The word “ethics” comes from the Greek “ethos” meaning “way of life”.

_items.title: Definition
_items.body:
Ethics is:

  • a critical reflection on values;
  • the study of human conduct and includes two parts: knowledge (knowing how to act) and action (making a decision and acting on it); or
  • about solving problems.

_items.title: Importance in the workplace
_items.body:
Ethics is what we are doing when we apply our values in our deliberations, decisions, and actions; it is how we live our lives.

If we accept that people’s values can differ, then we can see how people’s vision of ethics may also differ. This  implies that our view of “ethical behaviour” may be different from other people’s view  and from that of our organization. This is why it is so important to discuss ethical issues in the workplace, to learn how to use dialogue to come to an understanding of the differences (in our knowledge) and to learn how to negotiate these differences (in our actions).

_items.title: Application
_items.body: Laws, codes of conduct, regulations, policies, and directives point us in the right direction, but it is up to us to discover the values these instruments support within a context so that we know how to act or enact the values.

title: Ethics Example 1
body: What is the rule here?

title: Ethics Example 1
body: And here?

title: Ethics Example 2
body:
Obviously, in adverse weather conditions you would slow down and not drive up to the maximum speed limit. What matters here is the context, and the value that we want to uphold in applying the rule in our action (that is, how we drive in stormy weather).

So, what value does the rule and our actions support in these circumstances?

title: Ethics Example 2
body:
What value is the rule upholding?

SAFETY

This is an example of how laws (in this case traffic legislation), codes of conduct, regulations, policies, and directives point us in the right direction. It is up to us to discover, in a given situation, what values these instruments aim to support so that we can better act or live out these values.

  • Consult, the CBSA Code of Conduct, Chapter 1, D. Expected Standards of Conduct

When we look at the CBSA Code of Conduct, each of the Expected Standards of Conduct needs to be interpreted within the work environment. If you look at each of the standards in the Code, the first paragraph states which of the CBSA’s values that particular standard supports. So, if you have some doubts about what to do in a given situation, ask yourself “What value should be guiding me here?” “What value is this standard upholding?”

This understanding of ethics is different from commonly held views of what ethics is about. Ethics as a “way of life” involves both your learning (knowledge) and your actions.

title: Ethics as a “Way of Life”
body: Ethics as a “way of life” involves both your learning (knowledge) and your actions. Ethics is much more than catching bad guys/gals. In fact, ethics is a skill that you acquire over time. Ethics is like a muscle that needs regular use.
instruction: Select the arrow to learn more information.

_items.body:
Ethics is about:

  • you

Ethics is about:

  • you

_items.body:
Ethics is about:

  • you
  • you working and living together with others
  • you working and living together with others to ensure the long range public good

If we frame this from our work perspective, it would look like the image on the next screen.

_graphic.alt: A whole network of individuals linked together

title: Three Levels of Integrity
body: There are three ways of understanding ethics as a “way of life”:
instruction: Select the different levels to learn more information about them:

back.title: Level 1
back.body: Personal Interests and Desires – The question to ask at this level is: “Is the organization serving me?” In other words, “Am I healthy and happy in my job?”

back.title: Level 2
back.body: Patterns of Cooperation – The question to ask at this level is: “Is my team serving the Organization?” In other words, “As a team, are we working cooperatively in carrying out our work?”

back.title: Level 3
back.body: Long Range Public Good – The question to ask at this level is: “Is the CBSA serving Canadian citizens?” In other words, “Are all teams working cooperatively across the organization to achieve the CBSA’s mandate?”

title: Three Levels of Integrity
body:
If I’m unhappy in my job, or focus only on myself at Level 1, I might not be as cooperative as I should be and may therefore disrupt the team’s ability to serve Canadians.

Let’s take a closer look at Level 2 - which we call “Patterns of Cooperation” to see how they operate in the workplace…

title: Patterns of Cooperation
body:
The second level of Integrity—Patterns of Cooperation—is about learning how to work together. We accomplish much more by cooperating in teams than what we could possibly do on our own. There are two key concepts here: 1) learning and 2) cooperating. Both are required for effective “teamwork.”

This second level of Integrity is about ensuring that cooperation works. If you get below the surface of the technical aspects of how a team works together and shed some light on how standards of conduct actually work when they are working well, you will find a whole set of obligations that are being met over and over again. We don’t often notice this until something goes wrong, or until we have to learn how to cooperate with new people, or work on a new task or new project that we have never encountered before. What appears as conflict might just be that team members are learning new patterns of cooperation.

Patterns of cooperation involve obligations, which can seem quite ordinary. They are different from a “getting-the-bad-guys” understanding of ethics.

These obligations include common acts such as:

  • showing up to work on time;
  • actively listening to understand others;
  • taking direction from supervisors and following through; or
  • completing projects on time.

title: Patterns of Cooperation
body:
Each of these cooperative patterns has its own ethical structure. When a member of the team does not fulfill their obligations, the pattern can go “off track”. This can happen at a meeting where someone does not fulfill the obligations of what a good meeting requires, for example, they show up late, they are unprepared and they interrupt others during the meeting. The whole pattern of cooperation can break down. This can also happen if members are not aware of others’ expectations or the norms, standards, and culture of a group.

One of the expressions used in human resource management is that “We hire people for their technical abilities and fire them for their behavioural faults.”

We tend to focus on the technical aspects of our work, and so we should, but the CBSA’s Code of Conduct reminds us that there is another important aspect to working effectively and efficiently.

title: Intersecting Patterns of Cooperation
body:
When we consider that our patterns of cooperation intersect with other patterns, there are literally millions of obligations being met over and over and over again in order to meet the Agency’s mandate.

It is quite astonishing when you think about it! It is the reason why we get our backs up when someone doesn’t fulfill their obligations. We feel something has gone wrong.

And it’s no wonder; it only takes a few people to decide not to meet the obligations that are part of the structure of cooperation to wreck the pattern. It ripples through the intersecting web of cooperative patterns. Hence, the expression, “It only takes one!”. And it is at these moments that we get the idea that ethics is only about getting the bad guys. Why? …Because we tend not to notice the awesome ethical structure of the patterns of cooperation when everything is working well.

When we are faced with a new task or issue or culture, we have to learn new ways of cooperating. Take for example, social media. We are learning new ways of cooperating together using these tools while still ensuring that we meet our workplace obligations and uphold our values of Respect, Integrity and Professionalism.

title: Summary
body:
Ethics is a “way of life”.

Ethics involves a critical reflection on values.

Ethics is about solving problems.

Ethics is a skill.

Ethics is about:

  1. you
  2. you working and living together with others
  3. you working and living together with others to ensure the long-range public good

title: Conclusion
body:
You have had the time to reflect on your values and compare them to the Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector and the CBSA Code of Conduct values.

You have seen ethics from a different perspective than the mainstream.

You have discovered the three levels of ethical integrity.

title: Code of Conduct: Features (cont'd)
body:
Another feature of the Code is its tone. It is written in a language that addresses ethical, professional adults who are respectful and have integrity.

However, it is important to highlight the boundaries of what constitutes misconduct for new recruits and employees.

The Code uses “Caution” boxes and bold text to highlight the absolute boundaries of ethical conduct.

See for example, the Caution box in Chapter 1, Section 4 by selecting the key icon.

_tidbits.theBody: CAUTION: We are not permitted to do anything illegal or contrary to the Criminal Code, the CBSA Act, or any legislation or regulation enforced by the Agency. In the unlikely event of being arrested, detained or charged—in Canada or outside Canada—with a violation of laws or regulations, we will immediately report this incident to our manager. This includes minor incidents, such as a traffic violation or Highway Code violation ticket received while using a government-owned or leased vehicle. We must also report to our manager, any contact or associations we have with known or suspected criminals outside our official duties, so that we can protect ourselves and the Agency.

title: Code of Conduct - Values
body:
“We are expected to integrate public sector and CBSA values into our decisions, actions, policies, processes, systems, and how we deal with others. Similarly, we can expect to be treated in accordance with these values by our colleagues and management.”

  • Code of Conduct, Chapter 1, A. Our Values

How do our CBSA values align with the public sector values?

title: Values Alignment
instruction: Select the buttons to learn about them

back.title: CBSA VALUES
back.body:
The three CBSA core values are:

  • Respect
  • Intégrité
  • Professionnalisme

These values align with the public sector values of: Respect for Democracy,

back.title: PUBLIC SECTOR VALUES
back.body:
• Respect for Democracy
    Respect for People
  •  Integrity
  • Stewardship, and Excellence.

Note that “Stewardship” is a new public sector value. This value expresses that, as public servants, we take good care or are “good stewards” of resources such as financial resources, physical resources—for example property and equipment—human resources, and the environment.

title: Values Alignment
body:
• Code, Chapter 1, A. Our Values
 

In the Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector, the values are defined and described in a section called “Expected Behaviours.” You will find in the CBSA Code that each value has a section called, “Our Values in Action.” These actions are a customized version of the public sector Code’s “Expected Behaviours.” They take into consideration our unique mandate, culture and ethical risks.

In the next slide, we will look at the value of Respect to illustrate how the public sector and the CBSA values are aligned.

title: Objectives
body:
The objective of this module is to provide you with an orientation to the CBSA Code of Conduct.

In this module you will be introduced to:

  • the layout and features of the CBSA Code of Conduct; and
  • the alignment of the CBSA values with the public sector values.

title: Code of Conduct: Contents
body:
The Code of Conduct is broken into four distinct chapters and an appendix:

  • Chapter 1: Our Values and Expected Standards of Conduct
  • Chapter 2: Conflict of Interest and Post-Employment
  • Chapter 3: Disclosure of Information Concerning Wrongdoing in the Workplace
  • Chapter 4: Disciplinary Measures and Resolutions of Issues Pertaining to the Code of Conduct
  • Appendix: Contacts and Reference Documents

 

Select this Icon to reveal additional information important to managers

_tidbits.theBody: Note that managers have 28 distinct responsibilities in the CBSA Code; consult “Manager’s Responsibilities as Referenced in the Code of Conduct” under Manager’s Tools on Values and Ethics on Atlas.

title: Code of Conduct: Features
body:
The Code was designed with an interpretive guide embedded in the document. This guide can be found in side-boxes on the right-hand side of the page. They provide tips, examples, clarifications, and links to relevant legislation, regulations, policies, and directives.

Note that these are not a part of the Code but rather they provide additional guidance to help you interpret the Code and/or find additional information.
instruction: Select the image to learn more information.

_items.title: Code of Conduct: Features
_items.body:
• Take for example the side-box next to Chapter 1, 2. Appearance and Hygiene
The box denotes a “Tip” or an example of “business casual” appearance. This is not a part of the Code, as the Agency does not have a non-uniform appearance policy.  However, it does have a non-uniform appearance standard -professionalism- which is in keeping with the CBSA value of Professionalism. If in doubt, consult your manager as to what appearance standard is considered professional in view of your job duties.

These side-boxes will be updated as new issues, policies and/or risks become apparent in order to keep the Code current. When the Code’s guide is updated, the version date will change and this will be communicated to all employees.

Updates to the Code of Conduct can also be found on Atlas.

 

Tip: At CBSA “business casual” may be defined as:

A collared shirt (e.g. dress shirt or golf shirt) or top/blouse that should be conservative.

Skirts and dresses must be no shorter than 3” above the knee.

Pants/slacks should be of a dress pant material, typically not solely Lycra or Spandex (i.e. not athletic wear).

Generally: Shirts with logos or a design must be conservative so as to not negatively affect the professional image of the CBSA.

title: Code of Conduct: Features
body: Select this Icon to reveal additional information important to managers

_tidbits.theBody: Managers are responsible for communicating the importance of appearance as a component of professionalism in the workplace. From time to time, managers may need to clarify and provide guidance on what is considered appropriate (or not appropriate) dress in the workplace given employees' responsibilities (e.g. specific job duties, level of interaction with the public, etc.). (Chapter 1, 2.  Appearance and Hygiene).

title: Values Alignment - Respect
body:
CBSA - Our Values in Action

Respect: “We uphold the Canadian parliamentary democracy and its institutions by: … providing impartial, objective and factual information, advice and support in a timely manner to further Agency objectives.”

VECPS - Expected Behaviours

Respect for democracy: Public Servants shall uphold the Canadian parliamentary democracy and its institutions by: …  Respecting the rule of law and carrying out their duties in accordance with legislation, policies and directives in a non-partisan and impartial manner.”

title: Values Alignment - Respect
body: One way of enacting both the public sector and the CBSA value of Respect is to be “impartial” and "non-partisan".
instruction: Select the images to see examples.

_items.body: Public servants have a right to engage in political activities as long as it does not impair, or is not perceived to impair, their ability to perform their duties in a politically impartial manner.
Examples of being impartial and non-partisan include the practice of not displaying political materials at work or using the electronic network (e.g. emails) to distribute political messages.

title: Our Values in Action
body:
Take the time now to familiarize yourself with “Our Values in Action” by reading

  • Chapter 1 A: Our Values.
instruction: Select all those that apply. I may be acting in a manner that is considered misconduct by doing the following:

_items.text: Discriminating against someone based on an individual characteristic such as race, religion or sexual orientation.
Making rude, degrading or offensive remarks about a colleague
Returning to work a little tipsy after a team celebratory lunch
Making a degrading remark about my manager on Facebook
Taking time off when I am sick

_feedback.correct: That is correct. Putting our value of “Respect” into action creates a safe and healthy work environment.

_incorrect.final: That is incorrect. Putting our value of “Respect” into action creates a safe and healthy work environment.

title: 2) Our Values in Action
instruction: I can work part-time as a trainer, using course material that I developed as part of my CBSA work.

_feedback.correct: That is correct, the correct response is false. In regard to the value of Integrity, we serve the public interest by refraining from using our official roles and non-publicly available information including the CBSA’s intellectual property, for personal gain. This is considered a conflict of interest. We will cover aspects related to conflict of interest in module 6 of this training.

_incorrect.final: That is incorrect, the correct response is false. In regard to the value of Integrity, we serve the public interest by refraining from using our official roles and non-publicly available information including the CBSA’s intellectual property, for personal gain. This is considered a conflict of interest. We will cover aspects related to conflict of interest in module 6 of this training.

title: 3) Our Values in Action
instruction: By letting our manager know that we have witnessed a serious misconduct incident, we are acting in a professional manner.

_feedback.correct: That is correct, the correct response is true. The value of Professionalism incorporates building trust and accountability by ensuring that serious misconduct is reported so that it can be addressed.

_incorrect.final: That is incorrect, the correct response is true. The value of Professionalism incorporates building trust and accountability by ensuring that serious misconduct is reported so that it can be addressed.

title: Employee Responsibilities: Ethical Leadership
body:
When we hear the term “leadership” we may think it refers to our immediate supervisor or senior management, but ethical leadership involves all employees at every level.

Research shows that when a new person joins a team, they will model the behaviour of the person whose job is most like theirs. So, if you are an administrator who has just joined a new team, you will likely seek out a more experienced administrator and observe their behaviour to determine what is and what is not acceptable. In that role, the more experienced administrator is an ethical leader—whether they are aware of it or not.

Managers are expected to remind us of what the boundaries of unethical and unprofessional conduct are and to address inappropriate behaviour or performance issues. However, on a day-to-day basis, their duties and responsibilities are different from ours. Also, they are not always present when ethical situations arise.

We can collectively improve the ethical culture of our workplace, guided by the Codes and Policy, or we can collectively diminish it by tolerating unethical behaviour. As ethical leaders it is our responsibility to understand what is expected of us in terms of ethical conduct and to consistently act in accordance with these expectations.

Before you proceed, take a moment to think about how you can be an ethical leader.
instruction: Select each tab to learn more information.

_items.title: Who?
_items.body:
All employees are ethical leaders;
We act as models for others.

_items.title: What?
_items.body: Ethical leaders consistently model the expected standards of conduct.

_items.title: How?
_items.body: Ethical leadership is a skill that requires us to learn how to think through an ethical issue, problem or dilemma before acting.

title: Employee Responsibilities: Ethical Leadership
body:
We are all ethical leaders

Select this Icon to reveal additional information important to managers

_tidbits.theBody: Managers should note that a performance issue is not necessarily misconduct as the employee may be inexperienced or may not yet have developed the necessary skills to perform the job. It is up to you as a manager to decide whether this is a learning moment or a situation that requires disciplinary action.

title: Employee Responsibilities: Ethical Leadership (Cont'd)
body:
“We are all ethical leaders whether we are uniformed, non-uniformed or armed employees; we act as models for others. […]

Therefore, more experienced employees and managers, at all levels, have a special role in consistently modeling the expected standards of behaviour outlined in the Code of Conduct for new employees, recruits and other CBSA employees. ”

  • CBSA Code of Conduct, Chapter 1, C. Leadership Conduct

title: Scenario 1
body:
When asked by their manager to justify a sick day, the employee submitted a forged medical certificate.

  1. Can you see any issues here?
  2. Referring to the CBSA Code of Conduct (Table of Contents), what sections might provide some guidance?
  3. In your opinion, is this inappropriate behaviour or a serious misconduct?

Think about it.

Then select the key to find out what the experts say.

_tidbits.theBody:
The main issue here concerns fraud, and there are three main sections of the Code that relate to this scenario:

  • Our Values: Integrity and Professionalism
  • Chapter 1, 1. Terms and Conditions of Employment, 1.1 Hours of Work
  • Chapter 1, 6.5 Legal Provisions and Fraud

This case would be considered serious misconduct and could attract a 20-day suspension up to termination of employment.

title: Conclusion
body:
The CBSA Code of Conduct has been designed as the primary reference document on ethical conduct. If you have a question, it is the first document you should consult. It will lead you to the other relevant documents (including the Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector and the Policy on Conflict of Interest and Post-Employment (TBS)).

However, it is your responsibility to be familiar with your terms and conditions of employment.  Therefore, you are encouraged to read and become familiar with the three documents that provide ethical guidance.

If you have any questions, have a discussion with your manager or contact the National Integrity Centre of Expertise.

We will continue to learn about the Code throughout this course.

title: Employee Responsibilities
body:
The CBSA Code of Conduct is clear that all employees, students, recruits or those working for the Agency by means of secondment/assignment or through an Interchange Canada agreement are responsible for acting at all times in such a way as to uphold the public interest and for exhibiting conduct in keeping with the Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector Code and the CBSA Code.

  • Code of Conduct, Chapter 1, B. Accountability and Professional Conduct.

 

 

Select on the key to find out what the experts say.

_tidbits.theBody:
The first paragraph of Chapter 1, B of the Code indicates that all employees are bound by the two Codes and the Policy.

Notice the different types of employment status included in the “all employees”.  Note that contract workers are not bound by the two Codes and the Policy; however, we ask that they respect the spirit of the Codes/Policy.

title: Introduction
body:
There are a number of sections in Chapter 1.

We will not cover them all.

But, as these form a part of your terms and conditions of employment, you should be thoroughly familiar with these sections.

We will take a closer look at Section 3 – Social Media, Section 4 – Private, Off-Duty Conduct and Outside Activities, Section 9 – Harassment and Discrimination, and Section 14 – Consumption of Intoxicants, Illegal Drugs and Smoking.

_graphic.alt: Table of Content - Values and Ethics

title: Social Media and Myths
body:
What is the myth in this comment?

“Why would CBSA be bothered about the comments I make on my private online site during off-duty hours?”

Watch the short video (three minutes) by selecting the play button.

Social media covers many other digital tools [Logos of various social media tools]

Even email and texting are social media tools Canadians spend an average of 16.4 hours a week online 83% of Canadians use the Internet

That’s more than 27 million people!

60% of Canadians use social networking and 1 in 3 use social networking daily.

This means that MOST EMPLOYEES use social media.

We need to know how to use these tools safely.

The lines between our professional and personal lives are blurring.

We are taking our work home with us and bringing our personal lives to work...

So to help... get to know user guidelines from either your own department or the Treasury Board Secretariat.

So what can and can’t we do?

Let’s take a look at the 10 most important points...

Just like the telephone, using social media at work takes a commonsense approach.

Personal use should not be excessive and interfere with your work.

When posting, remember your comments are public for all the world to see comment online the same way you would at a meeting, over coffee or a public forum.

This means don’t discuss CONFIDENTIAL or classified material.

[Top Secret, Secret, Confidential, Protected A, B or C]

Respect Copyright, respect Privacy, be Polite.

Employees are expected to treat their peers with respect both in the physical workplace and online.

The Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector still applies.

Whether or not it’s clear who you work for be clear your views are your own.

Avoid the perception of deception. Be clear and transparent.

Using official logos or insignia may imply you are authorized to speak on behalf of the government.

You’re probably not.

On your social media networks you only represent yourself.

You need special training and prior approval to post, tweet or blog for the Government.

But official or not, inappropriate remarks could damage the government’s, a colleague’s, or your own reputation.

Ask yourself: “Would I want my manager seeing this?”

Always think twice.

In short: Protect Privacy, respect the Guideline and remember your public servant responsibilities.

Let your manager know if things go wrong.

So get started today and get to know social media at work.

[Canada wordmark]

[Adapted for use with permission from the Department of Justice (Victoria, Australia).]

[Music stops abruptly]

title: Social Media Ethics
body:
What is the myth in this comment?

“Why would CBSA be bothered about the comments I make on my private online site during off-duty hours?”

ANSWER:

There is no such thing as privacy when commenting online!

Lets look at a scenario related to the social media myth.

 

Select the key to find out what the experts say.

_tidbits.theBody:
The Treasury Board Secretariat’s (TBS) Policy on Acceptable Network Device and Use states that employees can access sites such as LinkedIn for “career development and other professional activities“ and “for limited personal use that is conducted on personal time,” providing that this access:

  •  does not interfere with the conduct of business;
  • is in compliance with the TBS Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector and the CBSA Code of Conduct; and
  • does not give rise to a real, an apparent or a potential conflict of interest or undermine the integrity of the Agency.

Consult the Security Awareness and Guidance on LinkedIn on ATLAS

title: Misconduct
body:
The CBSA Code identifies two levels of misconduct.

  1. Inappropriate behaviour
  2. Serious misconduct
instruction: Select each tab to learn more information.

_items.title: Misconduct – Inappropriate behaviour
_items.body:
It is the responsibility of management to address incidents involving inappropriate behaviour

However, there are times when a manager is not aware of the situation and the behaviour of another colleague is affecting our work. As an ethical leader what can we do?

  • If you feel comfortable and there is no personal risk to you, you may want to discuss this with the colleague who is not performing according to the Codes and/or Policy.
  • You can speak to another manager.
  • You can contact an advisor in the National Integrity Centre of Expertise to discuss your options.
  • You can seek one-on-one coaching on how to have a difficult conversation with an Informal Conflict Management System advisor.

_items.title: Serious misconduct
_items.body:
If you are involved in serious misconduct or if you witness serious misconduct you must promptly report this to your manager. In turn your manager will report this to Security and Professional Standards.

If the serious misconduct involves witnessing harassing behaviour or if you are a victim of this behaviour, you can speak to your manager or the National Integrity Centre of Expertise. Note that we will be discussing harassment later in this training.

title: Social Media Ethics
body:
1. Social media is here to stay
2. Social media postings are not private
3. You are bound by certain restrictions off and on-duty

title: Scenario 1
body:
Anil and Sandra work together but they don’t see eye-to-eye on most things and they just put up with each other. Things got worse one day. Sandra was working on a project and she needed Anil to help out. Anil, however, wasn’t clear on Sandra’s instructions so he asked her a number of questions. She responded by rolling her eyes.

The next day, a colleague sent Anil an email, cc’ing the entire team with a copy and paste of Sandra’s Facebook post and one of her tweets. They read “Why do we hire such idiots? I don’t get it! #idiotemployees#CBSA.”

  1. Can you see any issues here?
  2. Referring to the CBSA Code of Conduct (Table of Contents), what sections might provide some guidance?
  3. In your opinion, is this inappropriate behaviour or a serious misconduct?

Think about it.

Then select the key to find out…

_tidbits.theBody:
There are a number of issues in this case:

  • Anil and Sandra are just putting up with each other rather than seeking to establish a working relationship. When Anil sought clarification, Sandra was uncooperative and made a disrespectful gesture by rolling her eyes. Note that making gestures that seek to intimidate is considered harassment. Harassing behaviours are considered serious misconduct.
  • Sandra made a derogatory comment about CBSA’s employees in a digital format (Facebook and Twitter) risking CBSA’s reputation. This is considered serious misconduct.
  • Anil and Sandra’s colleague used CBSA’s electronic network to spread Sandra’s derogatory comments. Misuse of the email system is considered serious misconduct.

Sections of the CBSA Code that can provide you guidance are:

  • Our Values: Respect and Professionalism
  • Chapter 1, 3. Social Media
  • Chapter 1, 4. Private, Off-Duty Conduct and Outside Activities
  • Chapter 1, 5.2 Public Criticisms of the CBSA and/or the Government of Canada
  • Chapter 1, 6. Electronic Network Access and Uses
  • Chapter 1, 9. Harassment and Discrimination
  • Chapter 1, 11. Contact with the People We Work With

Other sections of the Code that could be implicated:

  • If Sandra used a government issued device to post on Facebook or send a tweet. Chapter 1, 14. Use of Personal Electronic Devices at Work

Notice how many sections of the Code are implicated in this case. More often than not, there is not one stand-alone answer to a question about ethical conduct.

title: Private, Off-Duty and Outside Activities
body:
The CBSA Code of Conduct recognizes that outside of work, your activities are private; however, there are certain activities which can place the Agency at risk and should be avoided. As stated in the Code, these activities include those that:

  • “reflect negatively on the Agency, its employees (including its managers) or its programs;
  • render us unable to perform a requirement of our duties;
  • lead other employees to refuse, be reluctant or be unable to work with us;
  • render us guilty of a breach of the Criminal Code; and
  • make it difficult for the Agency to manage its operations efficiently and/or to direct its workforce. “

title: Private, Off-Duty and Outside Activities (Cont'd)
body:
Chapter 1, Section 4 stresses the importance of reporting criminal activity and/or associations.

You should report to your manager any criminal activity or association.

A good test to determine criminal association is to ask yourself if:

Select the key to find out what the experts say.

_tidbits.theBody:
The CBSA Code defines harassment as any conduct by an individual that is directed at and offensive to another person or persons in the workplace, and that the individual knew or ought to have reasonably known would cause offence or harm. It comprises any objectionable act, comment or display that demeans, belittles, or causes personal humiliation or embarrassment, and any act of intimidation or threat. It includes harassment within the meaning of the Canadian Human Rights Act.

CBSA Senior Management has highlighted the importance for employees and managers at all levels to realize a "zero tolerance" approach for ensuring that the workplace is free from harassment.

  • Consult, CBSA Code, Chapter 1, 9. Harassment and Discrimination

title: Harassment - Activity
instruction: Do you know the difference of what constitutes harassment what does not?

_items.text: Making rude, degrading or offensive remarks or making gestures that seek to intimidate
Spreading malicious gossip or rumours about a person or ridiculing, humiliating, or abusing a person
Setting a person up to fail
Repeatedly singling out a person for meaningless tasks that are not a part of their normal duties
Making fun or his/her beliefs, values, religious convictions
Normal assignment of work by a manager
Constructive and respectful feedback during a PMA meeting
Application of progressive discipline when warranted
Workplace conflict (providing it is being resolved)
A single or isolated incident such as an inappropriate remark
Social relationship welcomed by both individuals
Friendly gestures among co-workers such as a welcomed pat-on-the-back

title: Harassment - Activity
body:
Please consult the Policy on Harassment Prevention and Resolution and the “Harassment” page on Atlas for resources and procedures on what to do if you are subject to harassing behaviours or you have witnessed someone being harassed.

Select this Icon to reveal additional information important to managers

_tidbits.theBody: The CBSA Code cautions that disciplinary or corrective measures will be taken against any manager who is aware of a harassment and who fails to take corrective action.

title: Conflict of Interest
body:
Conflict of Interest Definition:

A conflict of interest (COI) is a situation in which the public servant has private interests that could improperly influence the performance of their official duties and responsibilities or in which the public servant uses their office for personal gain.

  • Code of Conduct, Chapter 2, B. Prevention of Conflict of Interest

Select the key Icon to reveal a key point

_tidbits.theBody:
Notice that there are two elements to the definition of Conflict of Interest:

  • Your private interests could improperly influence you in your work.
  • You could use your official position for personal gain.

title: Conflict of Interest (cont'd)
body:
There are different kinds of conflict of interest. There can also be conflicts of duties.

Select on the Bulb Icon to find additional information.

_tidbits.theBody:
The “Threader Test” provides a good question to help decide if the situation is an apparent conflict of interest.

According to the Federal Court of Appeal in Threader, the existence of an apparent conflict of interest must be determined by the following question:

"Would an informed person, viewing the matter realistically and practically and having thought the matter through, think it more likely than not that the public servant, whether consciously or unconsciously, will be influenced in the performance of his/her official duties by considerations having to do with his private interests?" -Threader v. Canada (Treasury Board), [1987] 1F. C. 41 (CA) paragraph 27.

title: Conflict of Interest - Activity
body: Mary, an Executive Assistant for a Director and Collette, an Executive Assistant for a Director General go out for lunch. Mary offers to pay the bill for Collette. When she goes to pay for the pizza, the restaurant owner states, “It’s on the house. We get a lot of CBSA employees coming here.”
instruction: Is this a Conflict of Interest?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

This would give rise to a Conflict of Interest! As public servants, we are not to accept any gifts, hospitality or other benefits that may have a real, apparent or potential influence on our objectivity in carrying out our official duties and responsibilities, or that may place us under obligation to the donor. This includes activities such as accepting a free lunch, free or discounted admission to sporting and cultural events, travel or conferences.

For additional guidance talk to your manage or contact someone at the National Integrity Centre of Expertise.

_incorrect.final:
You did not select the correct response.

This would give rise to a Conflict of Interest! As public servants, we are not to accept any gifts, hospitality or other benefits that may have a real, apparent or potential influence on our objectivity in carrying out our official duties and responsibilities, or that may place us under obligation to the donor. This includes activities such as accepting a free lunch, free or discounted admission to sporting and cultural events, travel or conferences.

For additional guidance talk to your manage or contact someone at the National Integrity Centre of Expertise.

title: Conflict of Interest - Activity
body:
At times it may be challenging to assess the risk and/or identify conflicts of interest.

See how you manage the challenge.

Below are four people who have identified several situations to their managers. Identify if a conflict exists and if so, whether it is real, apparent, potential or a conflict of duties

title: Conflict of Interest - Activity
body: Gérard is on an acting assignment as a human resources advisor. His neighbor lets him know that she has just applied for a job at the CBSA which was advertised externally.
instruction: Is this a Conflict of Interest?

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

This could give rise to a Conflict of Interest! As public servants, we are responsible for demonstrating objectivity and impartiality in the exercise of our duties and in our decision-making, whether related to staffing, financial awards or penalties to external parties, transfer payments, program operations or any other exercise of responsibility.

This means that we are prohibited from granting preferential treatment or advantages to family, friends or any other person or entity. We are not to offer extraordinary assistance to any entity or persons already dealing with the government without the knowledge and support of our supervisor. We also are not to disadvantage any entity or persons dealing with the government because of personal antagonism or bias.

_incorrect.final:
You did not select the correct response.

This could give rise to a Conflict of Interest! As public servants, we are responsible for demonstrating objectivity and impartiality in the exercise of our duties and in our decision-making, whether related to staffing, financial awards or penalties to external parties, transfer payments, program operations or any other exercise of responsibility.

This means that we are prohibited from granting preferential treatment or advantages to family, friends or any other person or entity. We are not to offer extraordinary assistance to any entity or persons already dealing with the government without the knowledge and support of our supervisor. We also are not to disadvantage any entity or persons dealing with the government because of personal antagonism or bias.

title: Conflict of Interest - Activity
body: Lucy, a BSO conducting examinations of commercial goods, works part-time for an outside business that intends to import goods in the near future through the Port of Entry where she works.
instruction: Is this a Conflict of Interest?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Generally speaking we may engage in employment outside the public service and take part in outside activities unless the employment or activities are likely to give rise to a real, apparent or potential conflict of interest or would undermine the impartiality of the public service or our objectivity.

After consultation with our manager and if there is any doubt that our outside employment or activities might subject us to demands incompatible with our official duties, or cast doubt on our ability to perform our duties or responsibilities in a completely objective manner, we are required to complete and submit a Conflict of Interest Report to our manager. In addition to reporting to our manager, we can explore our options with the CBSA's Office of Values and Ethics. The final decision rests with our Director General or the Regional Director General, who may require that outside activities be modified or discontinued if it is determined that there is a real, apparent or potential conflict of interest.

_incorrect.final:
You did not select the correct response.

Generally speaking we may engage in employment outside the public service and take part in outside activities unless the employment or activities are likely to give rise to a real, apparent or potential conflict of interest or would undermine the impartiality of the public service or our objectivity.

After consultation with our manager and if there is any doubt that our outside employment or activities might subject us to demands incompatible with our official duties, or cast doubt on our ability to perform our duties or responsibilities in a completely objective manner, we are required to complete and submit a Conflict of Interest Report to our manager. In addition to reporting to our manager, we can explore our options with the CBSA's Office of Values and Ethics. The final decision rests with our Director General or the Regional Director General, who may require that outside activities be modified or discontinued if it is determined that there is a real, apparent or potential conflict of interest.

title: Conflict of Interest - Activity
body: A Health Canada doctor, in an official capacity, is asked to sit on a hospital research board. This board seeks funding from Health Canada.
instruction: Is this a Conflict of Interest?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Yes, this could give rise to a Conflict of Interest, not because of a public servant's private interests, but as a result of one or more concurrent or competing official responsibilities. For example, these roles could include his or her primary public service employment and his or her responsibilities in an outside role that forms part of his or her official duties, such as an appointment to a board of directors, or other outside function.

After consultation with our manager and if there is any doubt that our participation in the research board might subject us to demands incompatible with our official duties, or cast doubt on our ability to perform our duties or responsibilities in a completely objective manner, we are required to complete and submit a Conflict of Interest Report to our manager. In addition to reporting to our manager, we can explore our options with the CBSA's Office of Values and Ethics. The final decision rests with our Director General or the Regional Director General, who may require that outside activities be modified or discontinued if it is determined that there is a real, apparent or potential conflict of interest.

_incorrect.final:
You did not select the correct response.

Yes, this could give rise to a Conflict of Interest, not because of a public servant's private interests, but as a result of one or more concurrent or competing official responsibilities. For example, these roles could include his or her primary public service employment and his or her responsibilities in an outside role that forms part of his or her official duties, such as an appointment to a board of directors, or other outside function.

After consultation with our manager and if there is any doubt that our participation in the research board might subject us to demands incompatible with our official duties, or cast doubt on our ability to perform our duties or responsibilities in a completely objective manner, we are required to complete and submit a Conflict of Interest Report to our manager. In addition to reporting to our manager, we can explore our options with the CBSA's Office of Values and Ethics. The final decision rests with our Director General or the Regional Director General, who may require that outside activities be modified or discontinued if it is determined that there is a real, apparent or potential conflict of interest.

title: Scenario 1
body:
You have been invited to teach a course at a community college. The course is related to your work.

The Dean asks that you provide real-life case studies as a teaching tool.
instruction: Is there an issue here?

_feedback.correct: That is correct. It looks like a conflict of interest. Please continue with the scenario.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. It looks like a conflict of interest. Please continue with the scenario.

title: Scenarios
body:
Now that you have seen the types of conflict of interest situations, it is time for you to put your learning into practice through non-graded quizzes.

You will be presented with two scenarios related to conflict of interest.

Please read each scenario carefully and think about them in terms of conflict of interest situations.

title: Scenario 1
instruction:
What type of conflict of interest exists in this situation?

If you need help, please see the glossary for definitions.

_feedback.correct:
That is correct. This is a case of a potential conflict of interest, as it hasn't happened yet. In this case, you should do one or more of the following:

  • Discuss this situation with your manager.
  • Fill in a CBSA Conflict of Interest Report within 60 days of being aware of the situation and submit it according to your region's procedures.
  • Don't start teaching a course related to your work unless you have discussed this with your manager.

_incorrect.final:
That is not correct. This is a case of a potential conflict of interest, as it hasn’t happened yet. In this case, you should do one or more of the following:

  • Discuss this situation with your manager.
  • Fill in a CBSA Conflict of Interest Report within 60 days of being aware of the situation and submit it according to your region’s procedures.
  • Don’t start teaching a course related to your work unless you have discussed this with your manager.

title: Scenario 1
instruction: From the items listed below, select the sections of the code that would provide guidance to you in addressing this situation.

_items.text: Chapter 1, Section 4. Private, Off-Duty and Outside Activities
Chapter 1, Section 8. Confidentiality and Disclosure of Information
Chapter 2, Section 2. Outside Employment or Activities

_feedback.correct:
That is correct.  All these sections provide guidance to deal with such a situation. Other sections of the Code that could be implicated include:

  • Chapter 1, Section 5.1 Publicly Commenting for the CBSA
  • Chapter 1, Section 5.2 Public Criticisms of the CBSA and/or the Government of Canada

_incorrect.final:
All of these sections provide guidance to deal with such a situation. Other sections of the Code that could be implicated include:

  • Chapter 1, Section 1.1 Hours of Work (if time spent on your  outside employment  conflicts with your regular working hours you should discuss this with your manager)
  • Chapter 1, Section 5.1 Publicly Commenting for the CBSA
  • Chapter 1, Section 5.2 Public Criticisms of the CBSA and/or the Government of Canada
