title: Scenario 1
body:
Now that you have had an opportunity to reflect and act in regard to scenario one.

Select on the key icon to see what the experts have to say about this particular scenario.

_tidbits.theBody:
The Code acknowledges that we may engage in outside employment unless it gives rise to a conflict of interest.

The main issue here is the “real-life” case studies.  Firstly, using case studies adapted from your insider knowledge of the CBSA would be using your position for personal gain. You would not have access to the cases or information if you didn’t work at the CBSA. Secondly, the CBSA cases could be confidential.  To use real cases, you require Agency approval and assistance to remove all confidential information. This is also true for cases that are publicly known. In addition, you would have to be careful not to offer your opinion on how the cases were handled, as you are not authorized to speak on behalf of the Agency.  Nor should you criticize the Agency and/or the Government of Canada while delivering this course.

title: Scenario 2
body:
One of your colleagues owns an outside business that sells beauty products. She advertises the business at work with a poster and brochures prominently displayed in the lunch room.

You receive an invitation to a lunch-time session in the boardroom featuring the products. The invitation was sent to all staff.
instruction: Is there an issue here?

_feedback.correct: That is correct.  It looks like a conflict of interest. Please continue with the scenario.

_incorrect.final: You did not select the correct response. It looks like a conflict of interest. Please continue with the scenario.

title: Scenario 2
instruction:
What type of conflict of interest exists in this situation?

If you need help, please see the glossary for definitions.

_feedback.correct: That is correct. This case is an example of a real conflict of interest as your colleague is using government property for personal gain. The poster and brochures displayed in the lunch room may or may not be an issue. This depends upon whether the employee had their manager’s approval to post these materials. Standards  vary  from workplace to workplace, as it is up to the manager to decide. There is a difference between passively advertising your own business by displaying materials in approved areas and inviting anyone who is interested to approach you after hours, versus actively soliciting clients in the workplace.

_incorrect.final: That is not correct. This case is an example of a real conflict of interest as your colleague is using government property for personal gain. The poster and brochures displayed in the lunch room may or may not be an issue. This depends upon whether the employee had their manager’s approval to post these materials. Standards  vary  from workplace to workplace, as it is up to the manager to decide. There is a difference between passively advertising your own business by displaying materials in approved areas and inviting anyone who is interested to approach you after hours, versus actively soliciting clients in the workplace.

title: Scenario 2
instruction: From the items listed below, select the sections of the code that would provide guidance to you in addressing this situation.

_items.text: Chapter 1, Section 4. Private, Off-Duty and Outside Activities
Chapter 1, Section 7. Care and Use of Government Property and Assets
Chapter 2, Section 2. Outside Employment or Activities

_feedback.correct:
That is correct.  All these sections provide guidance to deal with such a situation. Other sections that could be implicated include:

  • Chapter 1, Section 1.1 Hours of Work (if this activity is interfering with your official work, then there is a conflict of interest)
  • Chapter 1, Section 6. Electronic Network Access and Uses (if the invitation was sent by email).

_incorrect.final:
All these sections provide guidance to deal with such a situation. Other sections that could be implicated include:

  • Chapter 1, Section 1.1 Hours of Work (if this activity is interfering with your official work, then there is a conflict of interest)
  • Chapter 1, Section 6. Electronic Network Access and Uses (if the invitation was sent by email).

title: Scenario 2
body:
Now that you have had an opportunity to reflect and act in regard to scenario two.

Select the key icon to see what the experts have to say about this particular scenario.

_tidbits.theBody: This case presents a number of issues, including the use of government-owned property (the boardroom) for personal gain and actively soliciting clients in the workplace. If the employee has invited her colleagues through her work email, this could also be inappropriate use of the electronic network. If the employee was senior to the employees being invited (e.g. supervisor or manager), then your colleague’s private interests are improperly influencing her work. Subordinates may feel pressure to purchase products from a supervisor or manager.

title: COI Situations
body: We have already covered conflict of interest in regard to outside employment or activities.  Now, let's take the time to uncover the other types of conflict of interest situations you may encounter in your on-duty and off-duty lives.
instruction: Select each folder tab to read about these situations.

_items.title: Personal Assets
_items.body:
Personal Assets

If you own or control assets or have liabilities that relate to your official duties, you might be in a financial conflict of interest situation. For example, if you own shares in a customs brokerage and clear goods from this company, you are probably in a conflict of interest situation.

You should consult the “CBSA’s List of Reportable and Exempt Assets and Liabilities” to determine what assets you should be reporting. This is found on the “Conflict of Interest Guidelines” page on Atlas. If you are in doubt as to whether you are in a financial conflict of interest situation, you should fill in a CBSA Conflict of Interest Report within 60 days of being aware of the situation and submit it to your manager.  If you are uncomfortable sharing your private financial information with your manager, you can request that your Conflict of Interest form be sent directly to the Office of Values and Ethics for analysis. However, you should notify your manager if and when the conflict of interest has been resolved.

_items.title: Political activities
_items.body:
The Public Service Employment Act (PSEA) provides definitions and guidance in terms of political activities and political candidacy. For more information on political activities visit the General Political Activity page on Atlas.  If you run as a candidate in a federal, provincial, territorial or municipal election you MUST first obtain permission from the Public Service Commission.  It is important to note that there are very specific procedures that you must follow prior to running as a candidate. You can find these on the Political Candidacy Request Process page on Atlas. If you have any questions, please contact the CBSA Designated Political Activities Representative.

Please note that political candidacy requests can take up to 8 weeks to process.

_items.title: Gifts, Hospitality etc.
_items.body:
This section of the Code is fairly comprehensive and we will be doing a case study on gifts shortly. However, there are a couple of questions you might consider when you are deciding whether to accept a gift, hospitality or a benefit:

  • How would this appear to an outside objective person?
  • Who is the gift from and what is their intent?
  • Is it to gain favour or advantage?

A question that comes up frequently concerns travel points (loyalty programs). For more information, see the Travel Directive or discuss this with your manager for guidance in a specific situation.

_items.title: COI Before and After Leaving Employment
_items.body:
If you are leaving the public service, you have an obligation to consider whether your post-employment activities could put you in a conflict of interest situation. If you have any doubts,  you should do one or more of the following:

  • Discuss this situation with your manager.
  • Contact the Office of Values and Ethics and speak with one of the Senior Ethics Advisors.
  • Fill in a CBSA Conflict of Interest Report within 60 days of being aware of the situation and submit it to your manager.

If you currently hold a position in the EX, EX minus 1, EX minus 2 classifications, or their equivalents, you are subject to a one-year post-employment limitation.

  • (Consult Chapter 2, 1. Post-Employment Limitation Period When in Designated Positions for more information).

title: Final Scenario
body:
As a CBSA employee, you attend a conference in your official capacity put on by the Canadian Association of Importers and Exporters. The Agency has paid for your travel and conference expenses. At the conference you participate in a random draw and win an iPad3.

What would you do?
instruction: Select the Real Case button to find out about this real case.

_items.title: Real Case
_items.body:
What the Experts Say

This scenario has been adapted from an actual CBSA case. The employee accepted the iPad3 at the conference and on her return to work asked her manager if she could keep it.

Some of the issues here include: 

  • the value of the prize;
  • that one of the CBSA’s stakeholders put on the conference;
  • that you attended in your official capacity; and
  • that the CBSA paid all your expenses.

There are a number of sections of the Code that provide guidance:

  • Chapter 1, A. Our Values (see Integrity)
  • Chapter 2, Section 4. Gifts, Hospitality and Other Benefits in particular Section 4.1 Acceptance.
  • Chapter 2, Section 4.2 Situations Where it May be Impossible to Decline a Gift, Hospitality, Other Benefits
  • Chapter 2, Section 6.1 Relationship/Partnership with External Stakeholders

Note that the Code states the following:

 “Although, the normal expectation is that we do not accept gifts, hospitality or other benefits, it is permissible if they:

  • are infrequent and of minimal value such as low-cost promotional objects, simple meals or souvenirs with no cash value (note that we use reasonable judgment to determine “minimal value” as it does not correspond to a specific dollar amount);
  • are within the normal standards of courtesy, hospitality or protocol;
  • arise out of activities or events related to official duties; and
  • do not compromise or appear to compromise our integrity or that of the CBSA in any way.”

 All conditions must apply before you can accept a gift. It is worth noting that accepting an Ipad3 does not meet the first criteria; this is not a low-cost item.  Also, it does not fall within the normal standards of courtesy, hospitality, or protocol.  Because the gift came from one of the Agency’s stakeholders, acceptance may also compromise, or appear to compromise, the integrity of either the employee or the CBSA.  Accepting the gift therefore would be in breach of the Code.

Other considerations would include asking, “Who won the IPad3?” The answer is that the CBSA won it; the Agency paid for the conference and you were there as its representative.  Consider also “How does this look from the point of view of an outside, reasonable person?” The answer is that it may look “fishy”. A CBSA employee shouldn’t be accepting a benefit from an organization whose members are subject to enforcement activities of the CBSA. At minimum this is an apparent conflict of interest.

In order to avoid these sorts of situations, do not participate in draws at conferences while you are attending in your official capacity. Sometimes conference organizers will automatically put all attendee names into a draw. In this situation, if you win, you can politely decline and ask to draw the next name. If you do accept a gift, you need to report this to your manager.

So, what should the Agency now do with the iPad3 given that its representative accepted the gift? There are a number of options available to mitigate the conflict of interest:

  • return the prize with a letter thanking the organization but explaining why this gift must be returned;
  • sometimes you can accept the prize on behalf of the Agency (versus yourself), but an IPad3 would be difficult to share Agency-wide and so it is not recommended in this case;
  • ask your manager if you can donate the prize to the GCWCC or to a charitable organization; or
  • contact the Office of Values and Ethics for more guidance.

title: Conflict of Interest (cont'd)
body:
If you believe that you may be in a conflict of interest situation (real, apparent or potential), you can:

  • Discuss this situation with your manager
  • Contact the Office of Values and Ethics and discuss the situation with an Ethics Advisor
  • Fill in a CBSA Conflict of Interest Report within 60 days of being aware of the situation and submit it to your manager.

Regional Directors General (RDG) and Headquarters’ Directors General (DG) are the delegated authorities regarding decisions on conflict of interest issues.

Finally, note that being in a conflict of interest situation is not necessarily considered misconduct. However, failing to report it and failing to abide by any measures that your RDG or DG has instructed be put in place is.

title: Conflict of Interest (cont'd)
body:
If you discover that you are, or might be, in a conflict of interest, there may be a number of options to resolve or avoid your particular conflict.

The Office of Values and Ethics uses “reasonableness” as the guide when considering conflict of interest situations and making recommendations to minimize ethical risk.

Select this Icon to reveal additional information important to managers

_tidbits.theBody: A number of tools have been created to assist managers in addressing conflict of interest questions with their employees. These can be found on “Manager’s Tools on Values and Ethics” page on Atlas.

title: Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDPA)
body:
The Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDPA) came into force on April 15th 2007. It is often referred to as the “Whistle-blowing” Act.


The Act provides a means for employees in the federal public sector to disclose information:

  • that they believe could show that a wrongdoing has been committed in the federal public sector;
  • that could show a wrongdoing is about to be committed sector; or
  • that could show that the public servant has been asked to commit a wrongdoing.

The Act protects disclosers against reprisal and also protects, to the extent possible, the confidentiality of all persons involved in a disclosure of wrongdoing.

title: PSDPA (cont'd)
body: Let’s dig deeper to understand some of the terminology.
instruction: Select each tab to learn more information.

_items.title: Reprisal
_items.body:
Reprisal is any of the following measures taken at work against a current or former public servant because he or she has made a protected disclosure or has, in good faith, cooperated in an investigation into a disclosure:

  • a disciplinary measure;
  • a demotion;
  • a termination of employment, including, in the case of a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, a discharge or dismissal;
  • any measure that adversely affects the employment or working conditions of the public servant;
  • a threat to take any of these measures or directing a person to do so.
  • The Act prohibits reprisal

_items.title: Natural Justice and Procedural Fairness
_items.body:
The terms “natural justice” and “procedural fairness” have similar meaning and are commonly used interchangeably. The principles of natural justice concern procedural fairness, which ensures a fair decision is reached by an objective decision maker. Maintaining procedural fairness protects the rights of individuals and enhances public confidence in the process.

Natural justice or procedural fairness relates to a fair, objective and impartial process that includes the following requirements:

  • All parties involved have the opportunity to be heard and submit information.
  • Alleged wrongdoers are informed of the allegations made against them.
  • Alleged wrongdoers have the right to be judged by an impartial and independent decision-maker.
  • Wrongdoers will be informed of a founded decision and its the consequences.

_items.title: Confidentiality
_items.body:
The PSDPA protects the identities of all involved to the extent possible. All information relating to a disclosure of wrongdoing is exempt under the Access to Information Act, the Privacy Act and the Personal Information and Protection of Electronic Documents Act 

If the disclosed information concerns criminal activity it will be referred to the proper authorities. Confidentiality cannot be guaranteed under these circumstances. Should the wrongdoing be unfounded, the discloser is still protected under the PSDPA.

title: Wrongdoing
body:
Wrongdoing: has a very specific definition under s 8 of the PSDPA, which is mirrored in the CBSA Code of Conduct.

  • Contravention of: Act of Parliament, legislature of a province, or related regulations made under such an Act;
  • Misuse of public funds or assets;
  • Gross mismanagement in the federal public sector;
  • An act or omission that creates a substantial and specific danger to the life, health and safety of Canadians or the environment;
  • A serious breach of a Code of Conduct; or
  • Knowingly directing or counselling a person to commit a wrongdoing.
  • Additional information on wrongdoing should include: “All improper behaviour is unacceptable and will be addressed by the CBSA, but not all improper behaviour amounts to “wrongdoing” as defined by the Act” and “Under the Code, it is mandatory for all employees to report serious misconduct, but making a disclosure of wrongdoing is voluntary”
  • CBSA Code of Conduct, Chapter 3: Disclosure of Information Concerning Wrongdoing in the Workplace

title: Wrongdoing: Considerations
instruction: Select each button to learn more information.

back.title: Wrongdoing
back.body:
Wrongdoing, as defined in the Act, engages the public interest and is therefore broader than issues of a personal nature, between specific individuals. It includes significant and serious errors or behaviours which can be systemic, repetitive or reckless in nature and can adversely impact our ability to do our work or fulfill our mandate.

For example:

  • Gross mismanagement that results in dysfunctional teams.
  • Fraudulent activities that go unaddressed.

back.title: Generally, not Considered Wrongdoing
back.body:
Matters that should be more appropriately handled by other internal recourse mechanisms are generally not handled as wrongdoing under the PSDPSA.

For Example:

  • Staffing complaints - Public Service Labour Relations and Employment Board
  • Discrimination - Canadian Human Rights Commission
  • Work schedule complaints - Grievance process

title: Wrongdoing: Considerations
body:
The following are some of the criteria used to determine whether or not to investigate wrongdoing:

  • Does the information disclosed appear to meet the definition of wrongdoing under S. 8 of the PSDPA?
  • Is this a matter that is in the public interest?
  • Is there any indication of problems of a systemic or endemic nature?
  • Has the disclosure been addressed by another recourse mechanism?

title: What Can You Do If You Witness a Wrongdoing?
displayTitle: What Can You Do If You Witness a Wrongdoing?
body:
While it is mandatory to report misconduct, under the Code, disclosure of wrongdoing is voluntary, under the PSDPA.

If you have reasonable grounds to believe that a public servant has committed or is about to commit a wrongdoing in the workplace, you have three options to disclose this information:

  1. You can talk to your manager;
  2. You can disclose this information to the Office of the CBSA Senior Officer for Internal Disclosure (SOID); or
  3. You can disclose this information to the Public Sector Integrity Commissioner (OPSIC).

Any one of the three options can be contacted directly.

title: What Can You Do If You Witness a Wrongdoing? (cont'd)
body:
When disclosing information concerning wrongdoing, you should:

  • Follow the internal procedures provided on ATLAS.
  • Respect the reputation of individuals by not making trivial or unsubstantiated disclosures of wrongdoing or by making disclosures in bad faith; and
  • Provide only information strictly related to the allegation.

For more information, consult the CBSA Code of Conduct,  Chapter 3: Disclosure of Wrongdoing in the Workplace and the CBSA Protected Disclosure of Wrongdoing Process.

title: Protection Against Reprisal: Who to contact?
displayTitle: Protection Against Reprisal: Who to contact?
body:
If an employee has made a disclosure in good faith and feels that he/she has been the subject of reprisal, he/she has the right to make a formal complaint to the Office of the Public Sector Integrity Commissioner (OPSIC). For more information, consult the Reprisals Complaints page on the OPSIC web page.

Only OPSIC has the authority to deal with complaints of reprisal. And a complaint of reprisal must be filed to PSIC 60 days from the time the complainant knew, or ought to have known, that the reprisal occurred.

 

Select this Icon to reveal additional information important to managers

_tidbits.theBody:
As a manager, you should be aware that if an employee discloses to you information concerning an alleged wrongdoing, you should not report this through the chain-of-command.  You are responsible for protecting the identity of the discloser. Call the Office of the Senior Officer for Internal Disclosure for guidance and next steps.

The “Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act  (PSDPA) for Managers” online course provides training on definitions and responsibilities.  It is available through My Learning, course code: F4042-N.  It is also available on CD.

title: Consumption of Intoxicants
body: The CBSA Code states that we never report to work impaired or under the influence of an intoxicant.
instruction: Select each tab to learn more information.

_items.title: What constitutes an intoxicant?
_items.body:
Any substance that may affect an individual’s ability to perform their duties safely and productively such as:

  • alcohol
  • cannabis
  • cannabis products
  • drugs – illicit or legal

In addition, the CBSA code states that employees occupying safety-sensitive positions are not to consume cannabis within 24 hours of reporting for regular duty, stand-by or overtime.

At the CBSA a safety-sensitive position is one in which the consumption of cannabis or cannabis products could result in a serious accident, injury, fatality or incident affecting the health and/or safety of employees, the public, or the work environment.

_items.title: What constitutes a safety-sensitive position at the CBSA?
_items.body:
It includes the use or handling or operation of:

  • defensive equipment including the duty firearm
  • screening or examination equipment
  • the operation of a mechanical equipment
  • the examination or handling of suspected or known toxic substances

Please consult the Policy on the Use of Intoxicants page on Atlas.

title: Conclusion
body:
You have seen how your on-duty and off-duty lives may, at times, intersect when ethics is viewed as a “way of life”.

Lets continue to look at the CBSA Code of Conduct, by examining Chapter 2, Conflict of Interest and Post Employment.

title: Scenario 1
body:
A manager was on a one-year extended leave. During this time, they used a government vehicle as their personal car.  For example, they used it to go shopping, pick up their children from day-care, to go to the Bingo Hall, etc. A member of the public reported this. It was also found that the manager used a government gas card to pay for the car’s fuel which amounted to an excess of $5,000.

  1. Can you see any issues here?
  2. Referring to the CBSA Code of Conduct, what sections might provide some guidance?
  3. In your opinion, is this inappropriate behaviour, a serious misconduct, or a wrongdoing?

Think about it.

Then select on the key to find out what the experts say.

_tidbits.theBody:
There are a number of issues here including the use of public resources (government issued credit card) for personal gain.  This manager was on extended leave but remained bound by the Values and Ethics Code for the Public Sector, the TBS Policy on Conflict of Interest and Post-Employment and the organizational Code.

The following sections of the Code would apply to this case:

  • Our Values (see  Integrity and Professionalism)
  • Chapter 1, Section 1. Terms and Conditions of Employment
  • Chapter 1, Section 4. Private, Off-Duty Conduct and Outside Activities
  • Chapter 1, Section 16.2 Care of Money, Credit Cards and Items Having a Financial Value
  • Chapter 1, Section 16.5 Legal Provisions and Fraud

There are times when serious misconduct and wrongdoing can overlap. It is up to the Senior Officer for Internal Disclosure or the Public Sector Integrity Commissioner to determine if the case meets the PSDPA criteria when a potential wrongdoing is disclosed. In this case, it was determined to be a wrongdoing. The organization required that the manager reimburse the cost of gasoline and that management review their administrative practices concerning vehicle use.

title: What is an Ethical Dilemma?
body:
An ethical dilemma arises when there is a conflict of values and when some harm may be caused no matter what you do.

What can you do when faced with an ethical dilemma?

title: The Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making
displayTitle: The Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making
body:
When you are trying to think through an ethical issue, problem, situation or dilemma, you will discover that you must follow four steps:

 

What is it?

 

1. Pay attention to all the data by gathering all the facts. Do not make assumptions.

 

 

Is it this or that?

 

2. Explore to understand by asking if there is something new to learn in this situation; is this something I’ve seen before or is this a new issue, problem, situation or dilemma that requires me to get new insights?
 


Aha! It is this. Am I right?

 

3. Make reasonable judgments by testing whether my explanations and insights are correct.

 

 

 

What am I going to do about it?

 

 

4. Move toward responsible action. Note that we might know what the right thing to do is, but if we don’t act on it, we may be involved or complicit in unethical conduct. Base your actions on what you know to be right and true, and then follow through with courage. At times this might mean refraining from taking action.

 

Then, act.

Source: Dr. Kenneth Melchin, Dr. Michael Stebbins, Dr. Morag McAleese

title: Example of Insight
body: Adapted from Dr. Kenneth Melchin, Living with Other People, 1998.
instruction: Select the rectangles below to learn the steps.

back.title: Step 1
back.body:
Imagine you are very focused on a task and enjoying an unusually quiet work space.

You hear something in the distance…a faint call. The sound interrupts your focus and the question that arouses your curiosity is “What is it?”

back.title: Step 2
back.body: You look around and out of the window you see some birds but off in the distance. You also see some grey smoke coming out of the building next to you. You wonder, “Is it this or that?” Did you hear birds or did you hear someone calling for help?

back.title: Step 3
back.body: You are really alert now and hear the sound more clearly as “Help!” “Help!” Aha! It is someone in the building where the smoke is coming from. But you ask, “Am I really right about this?” Does the evidence support my answer?

back.title: Step 4
back.body:
If your answer is “yes” then you might ask, “What am I going to do about it?” This is the ethical moment, the moment that draws on your integrity.

We formulate our strategy (and sometimes this is done in seconds) and then we implement it in action.

title: The Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making
displayTitle: The Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making
body: This is a self-correcting method to ethical decision-making.

title: The Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making (cont'd)
displayTitle: The Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making (cont'd)
body:
Review the Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making

Note: this is a natural process of thinking, but at times we often do unnatural things.

E.g. if we are hungry, it is natural to eat or if we are tired, it is natural to rest - but we don’t always do what is natural.

When faced with an ethical issue, problem, situation or dilemma, we often skip one or more of the steps.

Examples:

We don’t gather all the facts and jump straight to action or reaction.

We assume we know what is going on (we don’t test our biases or assumptions) and jump straight to action.

We’ve got all the facts, we know what we should do but we don’t act. ( “It’s none of my business”; “It’s really the manager’s job”; “I don’t have the time.” etc.) .

Being attentive to how you make ethical decisions and how you act is a skill  that enhances your ethical leadership.

title: The Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making - Case of the Skier
displayTitle: The Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making - Case of the Skier
body:
1. Using the Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making, decide what you are going to do about the situation.
  2. What CBSA values guide you in this situation?

Open the “Charity case: Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making” in the Learning Resources toolbar to find what the experts say.

The Insight Method to Ethical Decision-Making:

What is it?
1. Pay attention to all the data.
Is it this or that?
2. Explore to understand.
Aha! It is this. Am I right?
3. Make reasonable judgments.
What am I going to do about it?
4. Move towards responsible action.
Then act.

(Source: Dr. Kenneth Melchin, Dr. Michael Stebbins, Dr. Morag McAleese)

title: Ethical Dialogue
body:
Ethical dialogue is helpful in resolving ethical dilemmas.

It is a meaningful conversation involving the respectful exchange of ideas, the suspension of judgments and careful listening (e.g., if you are working on your answer while someone is speaking, you are not really listening).

Dialogue is helpful in resolving ethical dilemmas; it allows individuals, usually in small groups, to share perspectives and experiences on difficult issues that they might otherwise just debate or avoid entirely.

Then select the key to find out what the experts say.

(Source: William Isaacs, Dialogue and the Art of Thinking Together, 1999)

_tidbits.theBody:
Dialogue provides an opportunity to gain insights into how and why decisions are made in the Agency.

It can help improve our capacity for ethical decision-making and lead to better ethical judgments.

We have discussed how both values and ethics can vary. These differences can be within us (competing values) or between individuals or groups. The high potential for individual and group differences means that sometimes we will interpret values and ethics differently and be affected differently based on our unique situation.

Dialogue is an opportunity for each of us to share our unique perspectives and to contribute meaningfully to ethical deliberation. This is especially the case when faced with an ethical dilemma or when values and/or ethics conflict. We benefit from having the skills to enter into constructive ethical dialogue.

title: Dialogue vs. Debate
body:
Dialogue is not just discussion, and it differs from debate. The table below contrasts the two.

Dialogue can lead to insights …

(Source: adapted from www.co-intelligence.org, The Co-Intelligence Institute)
instruction: Select each button to learn more information.

back.title: Dialogue
back.body:
Collaborative

Goal:  to find common ground

We listen to understand

We reflect on our position

Opens possibilities of reaching a better decision

Assume that many people have pieces of the answer

back.title: Debate
back.body:
Oppositional

Goal: to win

We listen to find flaws

We criticize other's position

Defends our own position as best

Assume that there is one right answer, and someone has it

title: Support
body:
If you experience an ethical dilemma and are in doubt about your decision, you can seek support from:

  • Your manager.

If your decision involves having a difficult conversation, you can seek coaching from:

  • An Informal Conflict Mediator.

If you are experiencing emotional turmoil, you can seek support from:

  • An Employee Assistance Program practitioner.

title: Conclusion
body: With practice, you get better at this process of ethical decision-making, learning how to have an ethical dialogue versus a debate, and you can become better at helping others develop these skills. However, you need to get some insights into the skill so that you can create the circumstances in your workplace that encourage ethical learning.

title: Introduction
body:
Now that we have learned some of the ways of exhibiting ethical competencies in the workplace, it is time to think about obstacles or challenges to ethical conduct.

This is important because obstacles can occur under certain conditions. By knowing some of these obstacles to ethical behaviour, you can prepare yourself to choose the ethical response.

title: Factors that Influence Ethical Conduct
body:
There are many different factors that contribute to perceptions of ethics and ethical behaviour in the workplace. These factors are generally understood to influence the ethical culture of an organization either by contributing to, or compromising, ethical action.

We are all subject to pressures from time to time, which is why it is vitally important to recognize them. It is also especially important to know how to respond to them. Raising our awareness of factors linked to ethical/unethical behaviour can help enhance the ethical culture of the organization.
instruction: Select on each of the tabs to the left to find out more about factors that influence ethical conduct at CBSA.

_items.title: Culture
_items.body:
A culture is found where there is a definable group that has a history of being together; the group members have developed their own way of doing things based on their particular work, how work-related problems are solved, and how decisions are made within the group.  New people joining the group are shown “the way we do things here” (source: Edgar Schein).

Take a moment to think about how you would describe the culture at the CBSA.

_items.title: Subculture
_items.body:
Subculture is a unique cultural subset within a larger culture. A subculture’s characteristics - such as expected norms of behaviour, conduct, and responsibility - are not necessarily written down or shared with the general culture. Cultural norms, standards, and values are both formally and informally transmitted, e.g.  through written procedures and unwritten behaviours.

It is important to keep in mind individual accountability when we think of belonging to a subculture. We need to keep in mind the importance of choice, and the ability to think critically and make up our own mind about ethical action.

Supportive and proactive subcultures can be effective for problem solving; however, identifying ourselves exclusively with one subculture can have negative consequences. For example, belonging and identifying with a subculture that believes in taking care of its own by ignoring stipulated rules or guidelines can result in unethical behaviour or unethical consequences.

Can you name some of the subcultures at the CBSA?

Select to reveal examples of groups that belong to a subculture at CBSA.

Inland Enforcement Officers

BSOs

Intelligence

Investigations

HQ and Regions

Uniformed employees, and non-uniformed employees

Armed employees and unarmed employees

Management and non-management

Smokers and non-smokers

_items.title: Internal and External Pressures
_items.body:
Internal and external pressures are those conditions or influences that may make us think, “Yes, but…” They give a context to our ethical decision-making that can lead us to make decisions we might otherwise not have made.

Health or family problems can also be a type of pressure, for example, if they significantly affect our sleep and so impair our decision-making.

Internal and external pressures can have enormous influence over our thoughts, beliefs and behaviours. Internal pressures come from our colleagues and the work environment. External pressures come from outside the organization (e.g. family, friends, and groups of interest).

Pressures can become problematic on the job, since their influence may cause us to do things we would not normally do, or that we recognize as being unethical.

title: Effects of Subcultures
body:
Positive Aspects

 

Negative Aspects

 

 

 

 

 

Select "Answer" to reveal some common answers and see if you thought of them too.

 

Answer

_tidbits.theBody:
Examples of positive effects:

  • Shared experiences and knowledge
  • Bonding
  • Common code of behaviour
  • Shared values
  • Supportive of each other
  • Trusting of each other
  • Understanding of the group’s strengths and weaknesses

Examples of negative effects:

  • Peer pressure
  • Decreased/diminished  individuality
  • “Group think”
  • Tendency to hold more extreme views/ polarized perspectives
  • Common ways of “getting around the rules”
  • Common understanding that “we don’t rat on each other,” which can lead to tolerance of inappropriate behavior, or even misconduct
  • Code of silence (note: this could be a positive effect if you work within a highly confidential unit)
  • Conformity to the group replaces conformity to the organization, and so organizational values may be rejected

title: Examples of Internal/External Pressures
body: Below are some examples of pressures that could influence your daily tasks.
instruction: Select the arrow to navigate on each image to find out more about these pressures.

_items.title: Reciprocity
_items.body: Reciprocity: the “you scratch my back, I’ll scratch yours” mentality. It’s natural to want to respond to people who have done things for us in the past. Even if we don’t mean to, it is possible to think differently about people we really like. This is why as public servants we don’t take gifts from someone we have influence over in our official duties.

_items.title: Helping people we like
_items.body: Helping people we like: when we work closely with people, we may feel comfortable sharing information about our personal life. Once that bond is created, we may feel uncomfortable not meeting their requests/ favours.

_items.title: The need to fit in
_items.body: The need to fit in: wherever one works, it is a reality that one may feel pressure to fit in and to commit acts that cement belonging to the group.

_items.title: Cultural obligation
_items.body: Cultural obligation: some cultures place a heavy emphasis on the sense of community and culture and it can be considered disrespectful to not do what is asked of us.

_items.title: Family relations
_items.body: Family relations: it is natural to share many things with close family members and it can be hard to know when to draw the line, including sharing stories about our work.

_items.title: Information in social settings
_items.body: Information in social settings: be careful of the information you share in social settings since you never know who is watching or listening; the “walls have ears”.

_items.title: Giving in to temptation
_items.body: Giving in to temptation: giving in to temptation for material or monetary gain, which can be an even greater pressure when someone feels victimized or “owed” something.

title: Stress
body:
Sustained levels of stress, over time, affect decision-making and ethical conduct in the workplace.

If you are suffering from signs of stress or from any other issues related to your personal well-being, please contact the Employee Assistance Program for support.

If you want to find out about the emotional rollercoaster (ups and downs) that may be experienced by employees in high stress jobs, click on the shovel icon below.

Select on the Bulb Icon to find additional information.

_tidbits.theBody:
Dr. Kevin Gilmartin, a police psychologist, worked with people in high stress jobs (e.g. police officers, paramedics) and studied the physical effects of stress on these workers.

He came up with what he called the “Hypervigilance Biological Rollercoaster” to explain the effects of stress on the body.  The rollercoaster describes an “on-duty high” and an “off-duty low”.  The high point on the rollercoaster is where people are “hypervigilant”, that is, constantly on the alert for risks, threats or high demands from their job.  They experience a sustained adrenaline rush.

Someone who is bullied at work can also be in a “hypervigilant” state perhaps because they do not know what will happen next, and are constantly on the alert for threats in the workplace. 

In a hypervigilant state, our adrenaline level is high.  When we leave work, and the stressful environment, our adrenaline level drops and we can experience a “crash”.  We can feel not only tired, but really “zoned out”.  We may not feel like doing anything, going anywhere, or talking to anyone.  Our bodies are trying to recover from the high stress levels we experienced at the top of the rollercoaster.  Our bodies normally need 18-24 hours to recover but job schedules, shift work, or constant demands can make it hard to physically recover from sustained stress.  People who feel good during the “on-duty high”, and bad during the “off-duty low” (when they go home) can mistakenly attribute this “low” to other factors, such as home life or relationship, with serious consequences.

If we are exposed to high levels of stress for a long time, we can experience the Hypervigilance Rollercoaster.  It can lead to being over-invested in work and to a sense of self that is closely linked to our professional role.

The problem is that we often can’t control what goes on at the top of the rollercoaster (in this case, on the job), which can lead to frustration and even a sense of victimization. This can potentially affect our decision-making and ethical conduct.

Dr. Gilmartin describes hypervigilance, and how it can affect ethical conduct and decision-making, in his book Emotional Survival in Law Enforcement.  This material may be of particular interest to front-line officers and others in high-stress jobs. For more information on Dr. Gilmartin’s work, or to borrow a video on this subject, contact your local EAP office.

If you are suffering from signs of stress or from any other issues related to your personal well-being, please contact your local Employee Assistance Program office.
